msItem.title: Poem on wine
msItem.incipit: 1r Aue color vini clari / Dulcis potus non amari / Tua nos inebriari - digneris potencia
msItem.explicit: 1r Ergo vinis collandemus / Potatores exultemus / Non potantes confundemus - In eterna supplicia
msItem.note: Poem of 5 stanzas.

msItem.title: Proverb on wordly transcience
msItem.incipit: 1r Preterit una dies nescitur origo secundi / An labor an requies sic transit gloria mundi
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Proverb on judgement
msItem.incipit: 1r Nullus in hoc meason dicat quicquam nisi reason / Nam iudex vendra qui cunctis premia rendra
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Names of the protector saints
msItem.incipit: 1r Nomina sanctorum sunt hec tibi vigiliarum Jo. Bap. atque Pe. Pal. Jac. Lau. S[?u]. Barthi. Math. Si sanctorum Andrew Thomeque Natal. / Mathei . Pascha tunc assen. Pen. trinitatis
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Three medical recipes
msItem.textLang: Middle English recipes with one Latin title
msItem.note: The recipes are for treating fever (Contra ffebres), injuries (ffor hym þat is brosten), and farcy in a horse (ffor an hors þat hath þe ffasshion).

msItem.title: Latin couplet
msItem.incipit: 1v Vano pede greditur clamorem demonis atque / Angelicas pennas caput avis habet
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Alphabet of Proverbs
msItem.rubric: 2r Incipit inuentum quod fert prouerbis tentum
msItem.incipit: 2r Ars est arbor amarissima cuius fructus est dulcisssimus et qui abhorret arboris amaritudinem nunquam gustabis fructus [crossed out: amarit] dulcedinem
msItem.explicit: 20r viri mites dirimunt lites

msItem.title: Medical recipe against parasites
msItem.rubric: 2v To geue a dranke for the bottes or wormes
msItem.incipit: 2v Allyger sycetrina
msItem.note: Unfinished. Added in the (?) 16th century.

msItem.title: Religious and moral instruction
msItem.incipit: 3r Happye his he that sarerve God well in everry commandement And especyall in three ther be passes all the reste that his for to saye: Love god above all thenge and Honner thy father and thy mother and Love thy naybor as thy selfe and thou shalt not doe amis
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the 16th century.

msItem.title: Note on the Creation of Fair Mead Park 1542
msItem.incipit: English The xxxiij here of yowre soffryn lord kyng henry the viijth that fayere mede parke was madde be twene medsovmmer and hallomas
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for treating a sore horseback
Parabolae
msItem.author: Odo of Cheriton
msItem.rubric: 21r Hic incipiunt parabole sancti Odonis de Ceritonia ad honorem et laudem ipsius qui est Alpha et O.
msItem.incipit: 21r [Q]uoniam ut dicit Gregorius plus est verbi dei parabolis
msItem.explicit: 23r qui cum beneficiris illi fforcius insurgit bello mouendi tibi
msItem.note: Unfinished.

msItem.title: Nine Virtues or Points Best Pleasing to God
msItem.author: Pseudo-Albertus Magnus
msItem.rubric: 23v Hit was an holy man and that besought god to send hym grace hym to teche suche vertues for to vse that myght best to lyfe and to soule . And he was answerd thus .
msItem.incipit: 23v 1. Ȝeve thyn hert to me and a peny to the pore for the love of me and it shall like me better þen þou yave all thy goodes after thi day
msItem.explicit: 23v 9. Loue me for me and it shall like me better þan þou make a piler rechyng vp to the heven stykyng full of rasors al thi body to rende ther vpon
msItem.note: Middle English version of the German Neun-Punkte-Lehre which accompanied the so-called Alberti-Tafeln. For other English copies, see Mooney (1995), p. 105. On the German tradition, see Auer (1952), 71-75.

msItem.title: Twelve points for purchasers of land to look to
msItem.author: Sir John Fortescue (attributed)
msItem.incipit: 24r Who so woll be wise in purse purchesyng Considre the poyntes that be folowyng
msItem.explicit: 24r And if þu wise purchessour bein x yere day þu shalt agayne þi money se

msItem.title: Poem on justice
msItem.rubric: 24v Hec in Ciuitate Gevennarum in Ecclesia predicatorum super picturam Judicij
msItem.incipit: 24v Iudicabis iudices Judex generalis His nichil proderit dignitas papalis
msItem.explicit: 24v Hic non erit codicis locus nec digestis Idem erit dominus Judex actor testis

msItem.title: Verse prayer for King Henry VIII
msItem.rubric: 24v Bod safe kyng hare whare he fer he go or ryde sent gorge be hys forman hovre blyssyd lady be hys gyde
msItem.note: Full transcription, copied by the same hand that entered the next prayer.

msItem.title: Verse prayer for Rowland and Mary [Rampston]
msItem.incipit: 24v Bod and hovre blyssed lady safe and kepe Rowland and mare
msItem.note: Full transcription, copied by the same hand that entered the preceding prayer.

msItem.title: Latin verses from the London Charterhouse
msItem.rubric: 25r Omnes isti versus scribuntur super diuersa hostia cellarum in claustro domus Cartusiensis London
msItem.incipit: 25r Bis duo sunt que mestificant me nocte dieque / En moriar sed vbi vel quomodo nescio quando
msItem.explicit: 26v Sit ibi sella placens pes ter due ad exteriora / Semper vbique tacens aude lege plange vel ora
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Accounts of Robert Rampston [Ramston] (crossed out)
msItem.note: Account of items and payments added in the late 15th or 16th century.

msItem.title: Poem against excess in men’s apparel [Variant version, including answer of the gallants to the clerics]
msItem.rubric: 27rMade by prestes ayenst Galantes and An Ansuere to þe same by the Galantes
msItem.incipit: 27r This prowde Galantes thriftles / Seyth hy Cappis witles / Stuffid dowblettes and longe pykyd shone / Hath broght this land in grete hevynes
msItem.explicit: 27r And afterward than ye may take in hand / All other to amend and bryng pese to this land

msItem.title: Account of St Edmund of Canterbuy
msItem.incipit: 27v Legitur de sancto Edmundo Cantuarensis Archiepiscopoe

msItem.title: Articles against Henry Standish (b. c. 1475-1535), Franciscan friar and theologian, concerning his defence of an Act of Parliament (1512) that restricted the benefit of clergy to those in major orders
msItem.rubric: 28r Articuli versus henrici scandissh fratrem minorem ac sacri theologie doctorem per Clerum Anglie
msItem.incipit: 28r Primus an licet Judici temporales conuocare Elitum in fero Judicali
msItem.explicit: 28r Quarto an princeps temporalis potest refreniare [...] debite modo non castigantes
msItem.note: The text is defective since the lower half of the page and part of the upper half has been cut out.

msItem.title: Latin verse
msItem.rubric: 28v Produc.
msItem.incipit: 28v Dic stratilates fortes validosque quirites
msItem.explicit: 28v Fures stratilates iuxta stratem latitantes

msItem.title: Copy of an indenture
msItem.incipit: 29r This endetur made betwene Master Robart Geyton and Master John Stern of hoos Parte being the partes the wyche I shall re hers to you by name the ffirst of them is callyd Master James of the North Countre being of the on[i]e parte and master sherwyne of the other parte ffor the wyche thees partes being present should swer that one Robart Wyght and the wyche was master geytons seruant wer ffallsly for sworne thys master geyton sung apon them a pargere the were a curised and ther fore wolde thys Master James wollde in thys mastere geyton wrongffully ther fore I pray you to se a remedy in thys mattere being in a sho[?n]che a nessessite and nede thys tyme - Jhesus Amen
msItem.note: The text is written vertically on the page. Full transcription.

msItem.title: Note about the birth of the first son (the later King Edward V) of Edward IV and Elizabeth Woodville on 2 November 1470
msItem.incipit: 29v The yere of oure lord [crossed out: Ml CCCClx] MlCCCClxx the xth yere of kyng Edward the iiijth then he beyng in fflaunders the ij.de day of Nouember on all soules day within the abbottes place at Westminster was borne Prince Edward the syest begoten son of the seid kyng Edward
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: 'Devoute and vertuos worde'
msItem.incipit: 29v Ther is no man so myghty but som man may hym dere / nor no man so witte but some man may hym lere / No no man is so variant but som man wil hym leve / Nor no man is so pacient but som man may hym greve
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Medical recipe to treat burns
msItem.rubric: 29v A good medsovn for bornnyng hor skalddyng

msItem.title: Copy of an indenture
msItem.incipit: 30r This Indenture made the xviij . day of September the yere of þe regne of K. E. the iiijth the xxth betwene John Gare of Seynt Mary Cray in the Counte of Kent Cordeweuer on þat oon partie and Walter Ryse son of John Ryse sumtyme of wymelton in the \same/ Counte ffuller on that oþer partie
msItem.explicit: 30r whereof the parties afore seide chauneably haue put there seales the day and yere aboveseide

msItem.title: Copy of an indenture
msItem.incipit: 30v Obligacio - Nouerint vniversi per presentes me W. M. de Bromley in Comitatu Kant. gent. teneri et firmiter obligari T. S. de Hese in Com predicit. et G. C. de Sellesden in parochia de Croydon in eodem Com.
msItem.explicit: 30v In cuius rei testimonium presentibus sigillum meum apposui. dat. tercio die april. anno r.r. E. iiijti vicesimo

msItem.title: Copy of an indenture
msItem.rubric: Condicio
msItem.incipit: 30v Condicio istius obligacionis talis est quod si willelmus infrabiligat. steterit et obedierit arbitrio ordinationi et iudicio N. S. gent. et R. B
msItem.explicit: 30v in omni suo robore stet et effectu

msItem.title: Copy of an indenture
msItem.rubric: 31r Relaxatio feoffatorum et alium feoffatum
msItem.incipit: 31r Omnibus Christi fidelibus ad quos presens scriptum peruenerit R.A. \ar/ Ric Couper T Jurdan et Johannes Jurdan
msItem.explicit: 31r In cuius rei testimonium presentibus sigilla nostra apposuimus datum apud C predict. xxviijno die Augusti Anno regni regi E iiijti xxjmo

msItem.title: Copy of an indenture
msItem.rubric: 31r Cart.
msItem.incipit: 31r Sciant presentes et futuri quod ego Robertus Sybbyng dedi concessi et hac presenti carta mea confirmaui Johanni ffayreman de Crofton in parochia Orpyngton in Com. Kanc. laborere omnia illa terre
msItem.explicit: 31r In cuius rei etcaetera hijs test. et caetera dat. etcaetera

msItem.title: Copy of an indenture
msItem.rubric: 31r General acquietans
msItem.incipit: 31v Nouerint vniuersi per presentes me Johannem abelle de lesnes in Com. Kans yoman remisisse et relax[i]sse Thome West de Eltham in Com. predicto
msItem.explicit: 31v pendentes a principio mundi vsque in diem confeccionis presencium in cuius rei etcaetera dat. etcaetera

msItem.title: Medical recipe for sick oxen
msItem.rubric: 31v De homagis regum Scocie regibus AngliA medssovn for sekke oxssovn
msItem.finalRubric: 31v and thys shall helpe them be the gras of god

msItem.title: Copy of an indenture
msItem.rubric: 32r Carta cum littera Attornatoria
msItem.incipit: 32r Sciant presentes et futuri quod nos R.A. armiger Ric. C. Robertus S.T.J. et Johannes Jurdan dedimus concessimus et hac presentis carta nostra confirmauimus
msItem.explicit: 32r In cuius rei et hijs testibus etcaetera dat. apud etcaetera

msItem.title: Note on lands
msItem.incipit: 32v Item iij halfe acurs a thys syd the wyllys
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Warnings of disease and death that hang over man (Memento mori text)
msItem.rubric: 32v How thov may remember thys that on the hangyth daly thys dessesys that here folovyth
msItem.incipit: 32v ferste the hed acakyh / the mygrene / the touvth ache
msItem.explicit: 32v than favlyth away thy tethe whan thov canste not fede than falyth away thy flesshe than son deth and prochyche the nere and nere and remember man what hoffer thy hed hangyth here

msItem.title: Historical account concerning English law in Scotland
msItem.rubric: 33r De Jure Regis Anglie in Scocia vt repertum est in Cronica Mariani Soctti
msItem.incipit: 33r Willelmum de Malmesbury Regir de Honden Henrici de Huntyngdon et aliorum anno gracie DCCCCx Edwardus senior filius aluredy regis subegit sibi reges scottorum et cumbrorum
msItem.explicit: 35v ideo a occisus est cui succesit Jacobus qui nu[n]c etcaetera

msItem.title: Tract on the legitimacy and right of succession at the end of the fourteenth century, favoring Edmund Mortimer as rightful successor to Richard II
msItem.incipit: 35v Memorandum that kyng edward the iijd lefully gate Edward his furst sone prince of Walis
msItem.explicit: 36v the thrid sone of the seid kyng edward the thrid to the wiche edmund the right and title of the seid corone and lordship by lawe and custume bylonged

msItem.title: Memoranda about the birth of Robert Rampston [Ramston]'s children
msItem.incipit: 37r The xvij here of the rayne of kyng hare the viij the xj day of decemer the san of the r that robard ramston was borne
msItem.explicit: 37r apprell - Item the xxix day of the xxij here of the rayne of kyng hare the viij that addre \ramston/ was borne

msItem.author: Accounts from Robert Rampston [Ramston] (crossed out)
msItem.incipit: 36v Item payd to hare wayte for hys wagys the xix here of the rayne of kynge hare the viijth saffe xiijs [iiij]d
msItem.explicit: 36v [not transcribed]

msItem.title: On the wreck of the bridge at Gloucester, 1192
msItem.rubric: 37r de Ponte Glouc.
msItem.incipit: 37r Qualiter pons Glouc. sumpserit inicius sic scribit vera narracio
msItem.explicit: 38v Per pie largicionis elimosinam et merite [crossed out: Beatum] Beati Nicholai qui vt dictum est hoc opus iniciauit fiant consortes sannctorum [sic] amen

msItem.title: Tract about the feudal oaths (homages) of Scottish kings to English kings
msItem.rubric: 38v De homagis regum Scocie regibus Anglie
msItem.incipit: 38v Nota uod tempore R. Henrici secundi Willelmus rex scocie de concensu procrum et regni sui magnatum regi henrico pro se et suis heredibus homagium et legiamentum fecit
msItem.explicit: 39v Et sic quatuor reges anglie receperunt homagium de iiijor regibus Scottorum ex quo henricus secundus post ipsum regnauerit

msItem.title: Legendary letter of the Sultan of Syria, Emperor of Babylon, to King Henry VI
msItem.textLang: Middle English with a Latin title
msItem.rubric: 39v Littera Soldani de Surrey ad Regem Henricum Sextum
msItem.incipit: 39v Weiting to all cristen men that I am kyng of all kynges lorde of all lordis sowdam of surre emperour of babilon steward of hell porter of paradis constable of ierusalem lord of ynd flour of all the workes and cosyn to crist and I am lord as farre as grasse growith or water rennythe
msItem.explicit: 40r and I schall make the kyng of Englond an Emperour or els meynteyn ynglond ayenst all and cristendoum and hethenes

msItem.title: Letter (response) of King Henry VI to the Sultan of Syria
msItem.rubric: 40r Responcio Regis Angli
msItem.incipit: 40r-40v Harry by the grace of gode kyng of ynglond and of ffraunce lord of Irelond Prince of Walis lord of Gyon and of Gasqwyn Erle of Derby Duke of Cornwal Erle of Chester duke of Lancester Conquerour of Scotlond and of his massege I thonk hym and of his sond and of this I take avysment tyll vnto the date of our lorde Ml CCCC xlj and then I schall geve and answere to hym
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Account of the damnation of a certain Pope Benedict
msItem.author: Peter Damian (attributed)
msItem.rubric: 40v Nota de rapina
msItem.incipit: 40v Benedictus Octauus nacione tuscanus ex patre Gregorio
msItem.explicit: 41r quod Episcopus fideliter explenit et Episcopatui cedens monasterium intruit et ibi vixit omnibus diebus vice sue

msItem.title: A political prophecy according to the throw of the dice
msItem.incipit: 41r When [six] is the best cast of the dyse and [one] berith vp [six] then ynglond ys paradise
msItem.explicit: 41r The lyon the rede rose and the flouredelyce The loke schall nede vn do yet {six} schal bere the price And {one} schall help there to

msItem.title: A political prophecy by the stars
msItem.incipit: 41r The blak schall blede the blew schall haue his hed / The white and the blewe schall torne al to one
msItem.explicit: 41r That after schal it neuer thyng ne keuerAnd Iubiter schall do this dede at dovere

msItem.title: Proclamation concerning relaxation of the Lenten fast (c. 1518-1529)
msItem.author: Thomas Wolsey
msItem.incipit: 41v The most reuerend father in god lord Thomas cardynall of yorke legate de latere of the see apostoliquie primat and chaunceller of England of his goodnes consideryng the scarsite and derth of fysshe and other customable vitayles for tyme of lent which hath happened this yere by thoccascyon of warres of shyppes perisshed in the see and other misfortunes by the auctorite of our holy father the pope sufficyenly vnto hym graunted in that behalfe hath gyuyn lycence to al maner of persones wythin the precynce of hys legacye that ys to say all the realme of England wych al other places beynge vnder þe kynges obeysaunce to vse and eate mylke butter chese egges and other whytmeatys aswel in thys tyme of lenton as other tymes forbyden without any scrupul of conscyence (excepte suche persones as by any expresse vowe or by þe ordre of theyr religyon haue promysed the contrary) Exhortyng and enioynynge vnto all and euery of them that wyll vse the benyfyte of thys sayd licence to say deuoutly euery sonday of thys yere knelyng on theyr kneees one Pater noster and one Aue maria for the good prosperous estates of our souerayne lorde the kyng the quene the Pryncesse and of the sayd lord cardinall Aue legate
msItem.note: Full transcription of this crossed out text.

msItem.title: Tract on the compotus
msItem.incipit: 42r Compotus iste diuiditur in sex partes
msItem.explicit: 42r Et sic annus bisextilis euenit generaliter in 4 anno Et causa quare annus

msItem.title: Three medical recieps
msItem.note: The recipes provide treatments for the farcy (A medsyn for the fassyon), sore throat (A soferayne medsyn for the colde horsnes) and numbnes (a good medson for the palset).

msItem.title: Historical accounts from the reign of Edward II, dating 1312-1320
msItem.rubric: 43r De Guerra Baronum
msItem.incipit: 43r Tempore Edwardi Regis de Carnarvon Anno Domini Ml CCCxjo Petrus de Gauerston decollatus fuit apud Gaueresythe inter kelynworthe et warwyk
msItem.explicit: 44v Anno domini Ml CCCxx in parliamento apud London vtlagati sunt hugo le dispenser pater et filius toto clero et rege consencientibus et [...] fecerunt statutum in quo
msItem.note: Unfinished.

msItem.title: Two medical recipes
msItem.note: Two recipes for treating ague (A good medson for \the shakyng/ hagu) and a wound from a thorn (A good medssoyn [crossed out: fforf] ffor the preche of a thorne) added by two late 15th- or 16th-century hands.

msItem.title: Epitaph of King Edward II
msItem.textLang: Latin poem with Middle English heading
msItem.rubric: 45r Thies \be/ som of the versys about the tumbe of kyng richard the secund which beth at westminster beside seynt edwardes shryne
msItem.incipit: 45r Prudens et mundus Ricards iure secundus
msItem.explicit: 45r Quemuis Regalia qui violauit
msItem.note: The name Thomas Cauendyssh has been added by another hand below the verses

msItem.title: Epiptaph of Simon de Langham (1310–1376), Archbishop of Canterbury
msItem.textLang: Latin poem with Middle English heading
msItem.rubric: 45r Thies verses be wreten on a tabyll hangyng at the tumbe of symon langham sumtyme abbot of westminster in westminster
msItem.incipit: 45r Simon de Langham sub petris hijs tumulatus
msItem.explicit: 45rNuncius ex parte pape transmittitur istuc

msItem.title: Letter from a student to their parents with a request to the father to send books for learning
msItem.incipit: 45v Ryght trust and well belouid ffather and mother I hartely recomende me vnto you praying you to send me your dayly blessyng ffather the cause of my wrytyng vnto you at thys tyme is praying you to sende me your dayly blessyng and for to sende me sum bokes ffor to lern of in the skole ffor I lake bokes to contende my lernyg at thys tyme and I haue them not shortely I shall ffor get moch lernynge
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the late 15th or 16th century.

msItem.title: My loue sche morneth for me (extract)
msItem.author: William Cornysh
msItem.incipit: 45v My loue she morns ffor me for me my loue she morns for me
msItem.note: These lines match with the opening lines of the song My loue sche morneth for me that survives in London, British Library, Add. MS 31922 where it is attributed to William Cornysh (1465-1523). See Siemens (1997), pp. 176-183

msItem.title: Verses on tithes
msItem.incipit: 45v Dande sunt decime vini frigum pecudiuque
msItem.explicit: 45v Qui ligat ex proprijs anathematizatio culpis

msItem.title: Birth entries for the Rampston [Ramston] family, 1525-1538
msItem.incipit: 46r The xvij yere of the rayne of kyng hare the viijth the xj day of dessember that robard ramston borne anno domini 1525
msItem.explicit: 46r The xxx yere of kyng henry the viijth the vj day of november that [...] \ramstovn/ was borne

msItem.title: Medical recipe for the farcy
msItem.note: Another copy of the same recipe, copied by a different hand, occurs on f. 42v

msItem.title: Medical recipe to treat pestilence
msItem.textLang: Middle English recipe with Latin heading
msItem.note: Entitled Contra pestelens.

msItem.title: Three medical recipes for colic and fever
Recipe for stewing fowl
msItem.rubric: 47v Item to [crossed out: seth] \stew/ w a cokrell
msItem.incipit: 47v parcely rote ffenell rote violettes
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Clericalis disciplina (excerpt)
msItem.author: Petrus Alfonsi
msItem.textLang: Middle English text with Latin heading
msItem.rubric: 48r Petrus alphonsus
msItem.incipit: 48r Ne aggrediaris viam aliquo nisi eium prius cognoueris et si tibi in via ignotus se associauerit iterque tuum investigauerit dic te longius ire quod disposueris
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Advice to avoid the counsel of one's enemy reconciled
msItem.textLang: Middle English text with Latin heading
msItem.rubric: 48r De vitando consilio illorum qui fuerunt inimici sed postea redierunt in graciam
msItem.incipit: 48r ffle the councell of thyne enemy reconsyled thowgh he speke fayre and go full lowe fforeuer fro the that
msItem.note: Unfinished. Full transcription. Mooney (1995) notes that the text is possibly in verse but it is not recorded in the (Digital) Index of Middle English Verse.

msItem.title: Menu for a marriage feast (2 courses) on the first Sunday after Easter
msItem.rubric: 48r The ffest at the mariage of G W and M F the sonday next after dominica in albis
msItem.incipit: 48r Nota the ffirst cours capon broth to potage
msItem.explicit: 48r with wafers ypocras
msItem.note: See Mooney (1995) for a full transcription.

msItem.title: Note on the capture of foreign ships during the siege of Brest, 4 Henry VII [1489]
msItem.incipit: 48v Apoun assencioun day the iiijth yere of kyng herry the vijth was ttakyn iiij shippys of ffraunce with ordinaunce goying to brestward to rescowe the castell with vecell and xx pipes of gonne powder and xij thousand crownes in money xxx speres complete
msItem.explicit: 48v Also the grete ordynaunce is comyn from nauntis to brest to maynetene the sege and conforme we englissh and john meton is cepteyn theryn

msItem.title: Account of the birth and christening of Arthur, first son of Henry VII, in 1486
msItem.incipit: 49r By the prouision of god our lady and the gloriuse marter seynt george on the xx. day of september . the fest of seynt Eustace the vigill of seynt mathew thappostill [crossed out: whi] wich was on a wendynsday a bowote on of þe cloke in the mornyng was borne at wynchester arthure þe firste begotyn son of owre souerayn lorde kyng henri þe vijth wiche was in yere of our lord Ml CCCClxxxvj
msItem.explicit: 52v And þen was borne to the kyng and the quene and had the blessyng of all myghty god our ladi and seint george and of his fader and mother and in the Churchyard were set to pypes of wyne that euery mane myght dreke and the kyng gaue gret largesses Memorandum that þe bisshop wessed at the fount with couerde basyns etcaetera

msItem.title: Prayer attributed to Queen Elizabeth of York, wife of Henry VII, in November 1500
msItem.author: Elizabeth of York
msItem.rubric: 53r This devoute prayer made the quenes grace Elizabeth late the wyfe of oure souereyne the kyng / kyng herry the vijth at Wodestok the xxvijth day of Nouember the xvjth yere of our seid souereigne lord and the yere of oure lord god .MlD.
msItem.incipit: 53r Jhesu welcome my makes welcome my redemer welcome my Savyour Jhesu Criste whome I here honour and make knowlege to be god and man in fourme of brede the secund \ persone / of the Trynyte
msItem.explicit: 53v-54r and for thy glorious resurreccioun and for thys most mervelous assencioun for thy blyssid and holy lyveyng and for the love that thowe haddest to al man kynde when thave woldest wilfully suffyr passioun for the redempcioun of synnrs haue mercy vpoun me and vpoun ald Christen soules Amen

msItem.title: Poem about transitoriness
msItem.incipit: 54r Munde vale tibi ve fugiebas dum sequerer te / Nunc tu sequeris me munde vale tibi ve / Mundus non mundat sed mundus poluit ergo / Qui manet in mundo quomodo mundus erit
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Two recipes for making rat poison
msItem.rubric: 54r A medssovn for to kylle rattys

msItem.title: The burn is this world blind [Christ's complaint from the Cross]
msItem.rubric: 54v Come ouer the borne besse
msItem.incipit: 54v The borne is this word blynde And besse ys mankynde
msItem.explicit: 54v And petyr refusyd My fryndes me abusyd
msItem.note: Incomplete version of the poem on ff. 55r-56r, crossed out.

msItem.title: Medical recipe to treat ague
msItem.rubric: 54v A good medycyne to help a man fro the ague

msItem.title: The burn is this world blind [Christ's complaint from the Cross]
msItem.rubric: 55r Come ouer the borne besse
msItem.incipit: 55r The borne is this word blynde And besse ys mankynde
msItem.explicit: 56r The water hit fallyth And Crist stondyth and callyth Come ouer the borne besse
msItem.note: Complete version of the aborted and crossed out poem on f. 54v. As Kuipers (2020) notes, this is a moralised version of a popular drinking song.

msItem.title: Accounts of Rowland Rampston [Ramston]
msItem.incipit: 56v the xviij yere of the rayne of kyng hare the viijth Memorandum that I rowland ramston hathe delyford to Jhon torkyn for the hole yere rente
msItem.explicit: 56v the xviij yere of the rayne of kyng hare the viij Item delyford to John st[...]don for the lordys rente [...] half [...] xvijs xd [...]
msItem.note: Most of the accounts have been crossed out but are partially legible.

msItem.title: Youth lust reaches or manhood [An Exhortation to God's Service]
msItem.rubric: 57r When all ys don and all ys sayd / God must be [crossed out: louyd] known seruyd and obeid
msItem.incipit: 57r Yougth luste Reches or Manhod / Trustyth in any of thes godes forbed
msItem.explicit: 58r ye se but few \pore/ pepull appere / maters of a moneth is not sped in a [crossed out: here] yere / When all ys doon

msItem.title: Accounts of Rowland Rampston [Ramston]
msItem.incipit: 58v the xvij yere of the rayne - Memorandum that I rowland ramston hathe takkyng on to farme sovers the farme of master pempys
msItem.explicit: 58v as yr hosbond did make [crossed out: make] takyn of hyr the xviij yere of the rayne
msItem.note: Crossed out but largely legible.

msItem.title: Two medical recipes to treat and prevent sickness in sheep
msItem.note: The recipes, entitled: A medssovn for seke shepe and for the rote to safe sechepe for j here have been copied by the hand of Rowland Rampston [Ramston].

msItem.title: Medical recipe for treating colic and the stone
Heart be true and do not amiss [Remember me poem]
msItem.incipit: 59r Harte be true and don not amys and thynk one them that gaue you this and euer among remember me

msItem.title: Three medical recipes
msItem.note: The medical recipes are for treating itch, colic and the stone, and to clean teeth.

msItem.title: Medieval mnemonic verses to distinguish Latin homonyms by the quantity of the penultimate syllable
msItem.rubric: 60r Deferencie
msItem.incipit: 60r Silua tenet leporem sapientis ligua leporem / set verbis lepidus aliquis factis que facetus / Discurrunt culices hominem turbando quietem
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Proverbs
msItem.incipit: 60r Lens lendis capiti lens lentis conuenit ori / Lens mordet per d mordetur si capit t / Lens animal lendis lens pro legumine lentis
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Verses (4 lines)
msItem.incipit: 60r Mutuo vult dantem set mutuor accipientem
msItem.explicit: 60r Mons est [crossed out: garnanus] garganus sed garganus incola montis

msItem.title: Verse couplet
msItem.incipit: 60r A moun primere commenseant / Soit dieu le piere omnipotent

msItem.title: Cato Major [Stanza 131 only]
msItem.author: Benedict Burgh
msItem.incipit: 60r Enforce thy wyttes for to lere / Aquaynt the wyth connyng for it is sure / Yf fortune chaunge and pouerte a pere / He that ys connynge ys lyke to recure

msItem.title: Titles of Thomas Wolsey
msItem.rubric: 60r Stilus Magistri Thome Wolsey Ebor. Archiepiscopi
msItem.incipit: 60r Reuerendissimum in Christo \pater/ Thomas miseracione diuina sancte Romane ecclesie presbiter cardinalis Eboraci Archiepiscopus Angliae primas et apostolice sedis legatus Cancellarius Angliae
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Theological poem
msItem.author: Bernard of Clairvaux (attributed)
msItem.rubric: 60v Barnardus ad Eugenium
msItem.incipit: 60v Miror de clericis cuius ordinis sunt in ornamentis ut milites
msItem.explicit: 60v Sed sempiternus horror inhabitans
msItem.note: Another copy of this poem appears to occur in Lincoln, Cathedral Chapter Library, MS 108 f. 4r.

msItem.title: Theological tract
msItem.rubric: 60v De Omeliaro doctoris festo Trinitatis capitulo secundo dicitur
msItem.incipit: 60v Omnis anima racionalis etate congrua distat fidem catholicam maxime populi predicatores Christiani et ecclesiarum dei doctores
msItem.explicit: 60v Nec sciens sit docere quod nouit

msItem.title: Poem on temptation
msItem.rubric: 61r In nomine patris et filij spiritus sancti Amen
msItem.incipit: 61r Si tu tempteris si demonis arte moveris
msItem.explicit: 61r Cessa condono pugna iuuo vince corono

msItem.title: Household notes on the purchase of sheep
msItem.author: Rowland Rampston [Ramston]
msItem.incipit: 61v Item for the shepe I hafe solde to robard lambe for xs viijd and therof a batyd xxd for hys wagyes for I toke hym xxd hom with hym and that makethe iijs iiijd [...]
msItem.note: The text continues on the upper half of f. 62r which has been cut out of the manuscript.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for treating burns and scalds
Medical recipe to treat mange in dogs
Medical recipe to treat 'heat in the liver'
msItem.note: The recipe is entitled: for a tysen for an \hete/ in the lyuer per Magistrum Ricardum phisioun.

msItem.title: Account of payment
msItem.author: Rowland Rampston [Ramston]
msItem.incipit: 64r The xxxij here of the Rayne of yow soffryn lord kyng henry the viij th the xx da of febreore payd to Wyllym corddell for xv thattyn gatheras of the same mony for vacar. of medow lyyng yn chenkford march a pene a uacar vd and a jd for the grovnd and the howse at chenkford lane end called oodherne
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Poem on those who take praise for others' work (extract from the Aeneid)
msItem.author: Virgil
msItem.rubric: 64v Opus cum fine merces sine fine
msItem.incipit: 64v Hos ego versiculos feci tulit alter honores / Sic vos non vobis nidificatis aues / Sic vos non vobis vellera fertis oves / Sic vos non vobis mellificatis apes / Sic vos non vobis fertis aratra boves

msItem.title: Recipe for making rat poison
msItem.rubric: 64v To kyll Rattes

msItem.title: Poem about the English
msItem.author: Pietro Carmeliano of Brescio
msItem.rubric: 65r Petri Darmeliani [sic for Carmeliani] scribe angli Carmen Responsum
msItem.incipit: 65r Conueniunt gallos crebris conuentibus angli / Et pacem iusta condicione petunt
msItem.explicit: 65r Angle petis pacem frustra nil amplius instes

msItem.title: Poem against the English
msItem.author: Robert Gaguin
msItem.rubric: 65r Gaguinus Orator Gallus contra Anglos
msItem.incipit: 65r Siccine tam crebris frustra conuentibus Anglos / Querimus et dubie pacis obimus iter?
msItem.explicit: 65r Tot vigiles curas sanctum mentibus amorem / Pedere defunctis regibus . Angle . potes

msItem.title: Poem to the Kingdom of England
msItem.author: 'Egidius'
msItem.rubric: 65v Ad regem Anglie
msItem.incipit: 65v Sis licet ingratus nec quid sit gratia cures / Exul ope nostra victor ad arva redis
msItem.explicit: 65v Abcessi nunquam sum quos amplexus amore / Sed semper socios federe suo meos

msItem.title: Verse response to the French
msItem.rubric: 65v Rex Anglie ad Gallum
msItem.incipit: 65v Non tua sed mea sunt que dicis arma iuuare / A me que proavi detinuere tui: / Hinc male dicis ope me superasse tua / Quod deus ipse velit faciam vel pace vel armis / Iouis sub clipeo singula ferre peto
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Suffrage to St Katherine of Alexandria
msItem.incipit: 66r Ad loca stellata duc nos katerina beata
msItem.explicit: 66r Monte sepulta syna bendicat nos katerina

msItem.title: Against swearing and blaspheming Christ in the use of oaths
msItem.incipit: 66r How darest thow swere or be so bold also To blasfeme hym that is very rote and rynde
msItem.explicit: 66r Thow shuldest be drawe and hangyd by þe chynAs a Traytour horrybill thogh þu were next of his kyn

msItem.title: Veni Creator Spiritus (hymn)
msItem.incipit: 66r Veni creator spiritus mentes tuorum visita
msItem.explicit: 66r atque filium te vtriusque spiritum credamus omni tempore sit laus

msItem.title: Poem on the Seven Ages of Mankind
msItem.rubric: 66v Septem etates - Infans inde puer adolesccens post iuuenis vir Inde senex fiat post \ea/ decrepitus
msItem.incipit: 66v Infans - In pannis iaceo viuo cum lacte papillo / lamentando fleo michi dum desit ille licor
msItem.explicit: 66v Decrepitus - Suffultus baculo iam tendo tripus quasi factus / In tum[u]lum currio caput inclinare coactus

msItem.title: Poem in praise of baldness
msItem.incipit: 66v iiijor magni fuerant in vertice calui / Julius et paulus heleseus et ipse Iohannes
msItem.explicit: 66v Tot fiant calui quot cupiunt hijs similari / vel crimes habeant dum rebeu omine fiant

msItem.title: A Farewell to the World
msItem.incipit: 67r ffare well this world I take my leve for euer / I am arested to apere at goddes face
msItem.explicit: 67r But at the last he yeveth hem a bable / when his peynted Cloth [...]
msItem.note: Ends imperfectly.

msItem.title: Verses for the feast of St Katherine of Alexandria
msItem.rubric: 67v De Sancta Katerina
msItem.incipit: 67v Disputando vicit virgo quinquaginta retores
msItem.explicit: 67v Nam qui eius passionem habet in memoria
msItem.note: For the same text from other sources, see Kim Kwang-Hwy, 'The Responsory Prosula in England' (Unpublished disseration, University of London, 1986), p. 158.

msItem.title: Hymn for Ascensio Domini
msItem.incipit: 67v Eterne Rex altissime redemptor et fidelium quo mors soluta deperit datur triumphus gratiae
msItem.explicit: 67v Gloria tibi domine qui scandis supra sidera cum patre et sancto spiritu in sempiterna secula Amen

msItem.title: Meditation
msItem.incipit: 68r sodenly for ther defaute and spared and forborn me in my grete trespace and synn whiche haue do myche more then euer \they/ dyd then thowe punysshed by grete trowbyls prisonement by opyn disclawnder bakbytynges blyndnesse madnesse and suche oþer and me vnkynd wreche þu callyst by scorge of softe and ese chatysyng of sykenesse somtyme by dethe of \my/ ffrendes
msItem.explicit: 69r And all we to gedyr thank the lord for thy yeftys of fortune laudamus te . and for thy yeftys of kynd benedicamus te for the yeftys of grace adoramus te and for thy mercyfull preseruynges and ware in this lyfe glorificamus te and for thy grete mercy done and shewed to me for my last reward gracias agimus tibi propter magnam gloriam tuam mercy lord of my grete trespace and euer gramercy of all thy grace
msItem.note: Begins imperfectly.

msItem.title: Note on confession
msItem.incipit: 69r Confessio est [...]
msItem.note: Full transcription attempted. The text has been crossed out. According to the Digital Index of Middle English Verse, this text is a heading for the next item in this catalogue record (Appeal of Christ to mankind by the pains of his Passion in Middle English verse) copied in the same hand. However, it seems more likely to the cataloguer that this line is a separate item and has no connection with the poem.

msItem.title: O mankind / Have in thy mind [Appeal of Christ to mankind by the pains of his Passion]
msItem.incipit: 69r O man vnkynde / Haue thow yn mynde / My passyon smert / Thow shall me fynde / To the full kynde / Lo here my hert
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: The ABC of Aristotle
msItem.incipit: 69v To auenturous to amerous ne anger the not to moche / To bolde ne to besy ne borde þu not to lange
msItem.explicit: 69v To wylde to wrathfull and wade nat to depe / ffor a mesurable mene is best for vs all to kepe
msItem.finalRubric: 69v Tene medium si non vis perdere modum

msItem.title: Poem on the evils of women
msItem.author: John Chrysostom (attributed)
msItem.rubric: 70r O maliciosum et acutissimum telum diaboli
msItem.incipit: 70r Per mulierum adam ab inicio a paradiso prostrauit
msItem.explicit: 70r Et per mulierem mundi lucernam Johannem baptiftam capite detruncauit

msItem.title: Thou gracious Lord grant me memory [Poem on the Passion]
msItem.incipit: 70r Thowe gracious lord graunt me memory Euer on thy passion to cry and call
msItem.explicit: 70r Be thowe defence and my mynd encreceThy kyndnesse to remembre and neuer to cese

msItem.title: Prayer to Christ
msItem.rubric: 70v Oracio
msItem.incipit: 70v Saluator mundi saluum me fac domine deus omnipotens et miserecors qui solus saluare potes Da michi scire velle et posse operare et perficere ea que tibi placita sunt et michi expediunt
msItem.explicit: 70v in affectu sanitas in consciencia humilitas in prosperitate perseuerancia bona vsque in finem prestante te . domine Jhesu Christe . Qui cum deo patre et spirit sancto viuis et regnas deus per omnia saecula saeculorum Amen

msItem.title: Indulgenced prayer to the Cross
msItem.incipit: 70v O nuda humanitas O magnum martirium / O profunda vulnera O virtus sanguinis / O mortis acerbitas O diuina dulcedo / Adiuua nos ad eternam felicitatem - Amen
msItem.finalRubric: 70v Summa Indulgenciarum iijMl Annorum coram crucifixo concessus est orationem precedentem dicenti
msItem.note: Full transcription. For other versions see Morse (2014) and (2024).

msItem.title: Instructions for tuning a harp
msItem.rubric: 71r To set a harpe factur per j stowell
msItem.incipit: 71r ffirst ye shall begyn to set youre harpe at the iiijth strynge and let hym stond still for your chef tenor and set all the harpe to hym
msItem.explicit: 71rand \so/ to the next ebenethe till ye come to the end and than shall youre harpe be well set amen

msItem.title: Copies of two indentures for Johanna Chamberlain, widow of William Chamberlain of Steeple Barton [Great Barton or Barton St John], concerning lands in Oxfordshire and London
msItem.incipit: 71v Oxon. Nouerint vniversi per presente me Johannam Chamberleyn nuper vxorem Willelmi Chamberleyn armiger defuncti recepisse et habuisse die confectionis presencium de Ricardo Chamberleyn ffimare manerij de Barton alias BartonseyntJohn in Com. Oxon
msItem.explicit: 71v per presentes sigillo meo signat. dat. etcaetera

msItem.title: Memento mori poem
msItem.incipit: 71v Sis testis Christe quod non iacet hic lapis iste / Corpus vt ornetur sed spiritus vt memoretur
msItem.note: The poem is commonly found in epitaphs.

msItem.title: Prayer of praise to the Archangle Gabriel
msItem.incipit: 71v Et benedictus sit ille gabriell qui tibi et toto generi humano fuit eterne salutis [...]
msItem.note: Partly legible due to smudging. Full transcription attempted.

msItem.title: Verse couplet on the Abuses of the Age (I)
msItem.rubric: 72r vulgus
msItem.incipit: 72r Etas ridetur . Mulier pulsatur . Amore / Diues laudatur . Paupuer adheret humo
msItem.explicit: 72r Oldmen ben scornyd Women arn wowed / Richemen arn glosed and pouere men bowed

msItem.title: Verse couplet on the Abuses of the Age (II)
msItem.rubric: 72r vulgus
msItem.incipit: 72r Prudentes ceci cognati degenere sunt / Mortuus ignotus nullus amicus [crossedo ut: adh] adest
msItem.explicit: 72r Wysemen arn blynde [crossed out: kynesby] kynesmen beth vnkynde / The dede is out of mynd and ffrendes may noone fynde

msItem.title: Verse couplet on the Abuses of the Age (III)
msItem.textLang: Latin and Greek with interlinear Middle English glosses
msItem.incipit: 72r Dum dolor est pragma [plee] mea dragma [peny] fit inde malagma [plaster] / Sit tibi sintagma multum valet inde caragma [print of þe peny]
msItem.note: Full transcription with added English glosses written above Latin words in square brackets.

msItem.title: Poem on the Signs of Death
msItem.incipit: 72r Whan thyne heed shaketh memento / Whan thi lippes quakyth Confessio
msItem.explicit: 72r Whan thi eighen holoweth libera me amen / Than deth foloweth venite ad iudicium

msItem.title: Verse couplet
msItem.incipit: 72r Christe tuos tua te gratis suscepimus a te / Ergo meos mea me merito nunc [crossed out: egigis] \exigis/ aue

msItem.title: Mnemonic verse for months of less than 31 days
msItem.incipit: 72v Ap. Se. Ju. No triginta dato. reliquis manis [sic: magis?] vno / Ni sit bissextus ffebrius minor esto duobus
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: List of abbreviated months of the year
msItem.incipit: 72v Ja. ffe. Mar. Ap. \May/ Juin. Juil Av. Sep. Octo. Neuem. De.
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Notes about the number of days and weeks in a year and quarter year
msItem.incipit: 72v Nota quod fuit dies in anno CCClxv - Et nota \quod/ quodlibet quarterium anni continet in se iiijxx xj dies - Qui faciunt xiij septimanas
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Notes on the four seasons
msItem.incipit: 72v Primum quarterium anni incipit xxxma die September et finit super xxixa diem December
msItem.explicit: 72v Quartum quarterium anni incipit primo Julij et finit super xxixa diem September

msItem.title: Notes relating to the lands of Isabella de Fortibus [Forz] (1237–1293) from the parliamentary rolls
msItem.incipit: 72v In Rotulo iiijto Regis Edwardi primi in res wiltes r.r. Carta quam Isabella de ffortibus fecit ade de Stratton de manerijs de Seuenhampton
msItem.explicit: 72v In Rotuloa xjmo Regis Henrici tercij de firma alloc. ville de Grymmesby
msItem.note: Isabella de Fortibus [Forz] (1237–1293), daughter of Baldwin de Redvers, Earl of Devon, and wife of William de Fortibus [Forz], Earl of Aumale, who inherited her husband's estates at his death in 1260 and those of her brother, Baldwin de Redvers, Earl of Devon, when he died childless in 1262.

msItem.title: On three sad things (perhaps excerpted from the Gesta Romanorum)
msItem.incipit: Sunt tria que vere me faciunt sepe dolore / Est durum primum quia scio me moriturum
msItem.explicit: Vitam Justorum fugiens exempla malorum / Hic non semper eris memor esto quod morieris

msItem.title: Memento mori poem
msItem.incipit: Non homo leteris tibi copia si fluat erit / Hic non semper eris memor esto quod moreris / Et manebit quod habes alter habebit / Corpus putrebit quod agis tecum remanebit
msItem.note: Full transcription. The exact same verses can be found on a painted scroll below a 'Hand of Meditation' on 15th-century woodwork, later incorported into a pew, found in the parish church in Bishops Cannings, Wiltshire. see Jean Michel Massing, 'Writing on Hands', Print Quarterly, 20:4 (2003), 415-418 (p. 417) [= Review of Claire Richter Sherman and Peter M. Lukehart, Writing on Hands: Memory and Knowledge in Early Modern Europe (exhibition catalogue)].

msItem.title: Maxims
msItem.incipit: Munus sit iudex fraus est mercator in vrbe / Jngenium dolus est et Gula festa dies / Ludus rustica est seca amor omnis voluptas
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Instructions for the Jesus Psalter (c. 1500)
msItem.rubric: The Psalter of Jhesu is to sey on the first pater noster thies wordys folowying
msItem.incipit: Ihesu mercy and graunt mercy / Ihesu for thy mekyll mercy / As tow art rote and well of mercy / So mercyfull Ihesu haue mercy on me
msItem.explicit: and on euery aue maria till ye come \to the/ next pater noster . Jhesu mercy and so on euery pater noster as it is above and ther for is grauntyd of pardon a Ml yere [crossed out: of pardon]

msItem.title: All is vanity save good deeds
msItem.incipit: What helpeth it man to be unstable / To sett his present lust on worldly vanyte
msItem.explicit: Save dedys good and badd payn or blysse / It shall not noy þe ofte to thynk on this

msItem.title: Poem on transience of worldly things
msItem.incipit: 73v Si tibi pulcra domus et splendida mensa / Si tibi sponsa decus et proles magna / Si [crossed out: tibi sp] superes socios in qualibet arte / Si Rota fortune te ducet ad astra / Tam cito preteriunt hec omnia nichil - quid inde?
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Poem about possessions
msItem.incipit: 73v Quondam res ui necnon et / Prestando tribui res possessas ad / Orans inde fui precibus pro rebus / Querere non potui perdebam res et amicum
msItem.note: Full transcription.

listBibl.bibl: "Pulchra domus (A e A+)" on MIRABILE Archivio digitale della cultura medievale Digital Archives for Medieval Culture

msItem.title: Proverb about wealth and praise
msItem.incipit: 73v Dum mea bursa sonat populus me laude coronat / laus est quassata dum bursa sit vacuta
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Poem about women
msItem.incipit: 73v Dum loculus durat omnis te femina curat / Dum cessas mulier tunc cessit amare / Nec cras nec heri nunquam credas mulieri
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Verse predictions based on the weather on St Paul's Day (fragmentary)
msItem.incipit: Clara dies pauli bona tempera [...] / Si nix vel pluvia designat te[...] / Si fuerint nebule pereunt an[...] / Si fuerint venti designat prae[...]
msItem.note: The text is defective because half of the page has been vertically torn off. Full transcription attempted.

msItem.title: Poem about justice (fragmentary)
msItem.incipit: 74r Lex iuris moritur fraus regnat [...] / lex est defuncta quia iudicis e[...] / propter et vnguentum ius est in [...]
msItem.note: The text is defective because half of the page has been vertically torn off. Full transcription attempted.

msItem.title: A Remembrance of Mortality [perhaps a translated extract from the Prick of Conscience] (fragmentary)
msItem.incipit: 74r Who so hym by thowght [...] / How harde it is to flitt fro [...] / ffrom pitt vnto payne þat [...] / He wold not do a synn[...]
msItem.note: The text is defective because half of the page has been vertically torn off. Full transcription attempted.

msItem.title: Verses admonishing the reader to trust in God (fragmentary)
msItem.incipit: 74r With wrong or noy ȝef [...] / Or fortune hath geven þe a [...]
msItem.explicit: 74r Teche not thy lord what he do [...] / He knoweth what thynges [...]
msItem.note: The text is defective because half of the page has been vertically torn off.

msItem.title: Scribal colophon (fragmentary)
msItem.incipit: 74r [...] est mea fessa / [...] me si male scripsi / [...]auit secula pomo / [...]s Adrifex
msItem.note: The text is defective because half of the page has been vertically torn off. Full transcription attempted.
The fragment appears to match exactly with a scribal colophon from the Latin life of Adam and Eve.

msItem.title: Verse couplet about time and money (fragmentary)
msItem.incipit: 74r [...] septima valebit / [...] annus habebit
msItem.note: The text is defective because half of the page has been vertically torn off. Full transcription attempted.

msItem.title: Liber celestis revelacionum, Book VIII, Chapter 39 (fragmentary)
msItem.author: Birgitta of Sweden
msItem.incipit: 74r [...] necesse est / [...] errores proprios / [...]monendo et corripiendo / [...]ando
msItem.note: Previously unidentified copy of one of Birgitta's revelations. The text is defective because half of the page has been vertically torn off. Full transcription attempted.

msItem.title: Fragmentary opening line of an 8-line fragment, apparently attacking extreme fashions in dress by appeal to Christ ‘vpon the rode’
msItem.incipit: 74r [...]thely lokys / [...] your bokys / [...] in torne clothis / [..] hat many men hym lothis
msItem.explicit: 74r [...]s many men doth fynde / [...]fere be hynde
msItem.note: The text is defective because half of the page has been vertically torn off.

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in folio. Folios 1-74: circle and rectangle with (?) crossbeam patterns.

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos.
The unfoliated modern paper flyleaves at the beginning and end have been allocated numbers between square brackets for reference purposes in this electronic catalogue record.

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint or hardpaint, frame only. Mainly single columns (except f. 32v, which has two columns. 20-34 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Written by numerous hands writing anglicana or secretary scripts, or combinations of these two, or in a version of chancery script.

decoNote.p: One small (1 line) plain initial in red ink and inside a frame of red ink on f. 35v.
One title rubricated in red ink on f. 33r.
Illustations of different sides of a dice drawn in brown ink inside the text on f. 41r.

binding.p: 18th- or 19th-century half white vellum binding with purple paper sides; five raised bands, partially exposed due to damage to the spine.
Binding height: 215 mm; width: 145 mm; depth: 20 mm.

origin.origDate: Second half of the 15th century (with additions in the early 16th century).
origin.p: Copied by various hands in the second half of the 15th century, with numerous early 16th-century additions by its first-known owner, Rowland Rampston [Ramston], and others.

provenance.p: Rowland Rampston [Ramston] (d. 1549) Rampston [Ramston], Rowland, d. 1549, gentryman of Chingford, Essex; and forester of Chingford Walk: notes concerning the births of this children (1525-1538) on ff. 36v, 37r (lower margin), and 46r match with children mentioned in the will of Rowland Rampston [Ramston] (d. 1549) of Chingford, Essex [see Alsop (1983), p. 162]. The same hand has added prayers for King Henry VIII, Rowland Rampston and Mary, his (?) wife, to f. 24v; accounts about payments (ff. 26v, 36v, 56v, 61v, and 62r); and medical recipes (20v, 31v, 44v, 54r, 58v-59r, 62v, and 63r). Rowland also added a note on the creation of Fair Mead Park in 1542 to f. 20v which indicates that he owned the manuscript for at least two decades. On the Ram(p)ston family, see Alsop (1983), pp. 161-164; Kuipers, 'Dulce et Utile' (2020), pp. 154-161.

Robert Rampston [Ramston] (1525-1585) Rampston [Ramston], Robert, 1525-1585, eldest son of Rowland Ramston of Chingford, Essex; forester of Chingford Walk (1549); and yeoman of the Queen's Chamber [see Alsop (1983), pp. 162-163]: accessed the manuscript or owned it after his father as suggested by his name inscriptions (Robart Ramstovn [2x]) on f. 59v.

Antony Rampston [Ramston] (b. 1538) Rampston [Ramston], Anthony, b. 1538, youngest son of Rowland Ramston of Chingford, Essex: accessed the manuscript or owned it after his father as suggested by his name inscriptions (Anthony Rampstdon on f. 70v. According to Kuipers (2020), p. 167, he was Keeper of Walthamstow Walk in Epping Forest.

One of the manuscripts of Thomas Gale (1635/6-1702) Gale, Thomas, 1635/6-1702, dean of York, antiquary and fellow of Trinity College Cambridge. The manuscript is listed as no. 201 (see the inside of the front cover ) in the list of Gale's manuscripts in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (1697).
One of the manuscripts of Roger Gale (1672-1744) Gale, Roger, 1672-1744, antiquary and scholar, son of Thomas Gale. Inherited from his father.

history.acquisition: Donated to Trinity College by Roger Gale (1672-1744)Gale, Roger, 1672-1744, son of Thomas Gale (1635/6-1702), in 1738. The alpha-numerical elements of its current classmark are printed on three (much worn) labels pasted onto the spine (O.2.53), and those of its current and previous classmarks are inscribed in the manuscript: inside of the front cover (C.6.9, O.2.53, and O.3.34 [crossed out] in brown ink); f. 1r (C.6.9) Its printed ex libris featuring its armorial coat of arms and name (Collegium S.S. Individuae Trinitatis in Academica Cantabrigiensi) pasted in the lower inner margin of f. 1r. Its modern library stamp on ff. 1r, 73v, 74v.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on M.R. James, The western manuscripts in the library of Trinity College, Cambridge: a descriptive catalogue, 3 (1902); and Linne R. Mooney, Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge The Index of Middle English Prose, Handlist XI (Woodbridge: Brewer, 1995).

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.
